awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Community College REU Site at Texas A&M University-Commerce
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Ben Jang, Stephen Starnes, and colleagues at Texas A&M University - Commerce host an REU Site that is designed to uniquely address the needs of the underserved Northeast Texas region and the neighboring states with a focus on the community college students. This student group consists of a large fraction of minority and first generation college students. The REU site will serve as a model for addressing undergraduate research issues for an important population in the higher education "pipeline" for STEM enrollments and one that is steadily growing nationwide. The project is funded by the REU Site Program of the Chemistry Division.

Close management of the program is supported by the weekly oral presentations, weekly faculty mentor discussiosn, progress and final reports, and a final symposium including both oral and poster presentations. To better expose students to "real world" research, two trips to world class companies and institutions are included in the activities. In addition, three workshops are scheduled to improve students' presentation and scientific writing skills and training in the crucial area of research ethics. The research projects represent critical research areas and the knowledge gained improves the fundamental understanding and accelerates the development of these fields. Research projects span a wide variety of topics in chemical and biochemical areas, including the investigation of metal and oligopeptide binding, chiral guest-host binding and sensing studies, and the conversion of glycerol into industrially-valuable organic acids.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the 2018-2022 REU project at Texas A&M University-Commerce (TAMUC) was to continue the previous successful REU projects by providing interdisciplinary research opportunities for a diverse population of community college students in Northeast Texas and the borders of Northeast Texas with Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana areas, who were unlikely to have a research opportunity before they commit to their pre-mature career paths. There are 23 community colleges in the Northeast Texas alone, which serve rural, urban and suburban undergraduate students. Approximately 50,000 of these students currently enroll in science courses and yet most do not persist to college graduation with a STEM degree. Nine student researchers per year are to be selected based not only on the GPA and career interest but also on the recommendation of the instructors on laboratory, problem solving, and non-cognitive skills. Special emphasis will be given to the underrepresented groups typically enrolled in the community colleges in this region and the next neighboring areas in OK, AR and LA.

Overall, the 3-yr project (2018, 2019, and 2021) recruited total 28 students from 13 different community colleges in the Northeast Texas region and the border areas and TAMUC. Out of 28 REU students, who did not have prior research opportunities, there were 43% minority students including 11 Hispanic and one American Indian. One female in the 2019 cohort and one male in the 2018 cohort are non-traditional students. One male student in the 2021 cohort is a veteran..27 of 28 REU students of the three cohorts continued to 4-yr universities to pursue their STEM careers. Of the 27 students continued to 4-yr universities, 15 of them finished their bachelor degrees while others are still pursuing. Two of the 15 graduated are currently enrolled in chemistry PhD programs.  

These REU students produced five publications in peer-reviewed journals and more than 30 presentations in conferences, such as ACS National Meetings, ACS SWRMs, Texas A&M System Pathway Symposiums, etc., since 2018.

Intellectual Merit: Experiences and momentum gained from the previous REU programs in 2013-2017 had been successfully applied to impact the undergraduate researchers of the 2018-2021 project. All three REU cohorts had the Frida-Saturday training visits in the Spring semester before the summer program to match with projects and faculty advisers followed by project training. REU students got to know other students in the same cohort and graduate and undergraduate students and faculty in the Chemistry Department of TAMUC. All REU students completed basic laboratory and project-based instrumentation training followed by intensive work with faculty mentors on novel research projects. Two field trips per year to world class companies and institutions, such as UT Southwestern and Eastman Chemicals, were effective in helping students connect basic research in the labs to applied research in the industry. The visits at UT Southwestern were very intriguing for students to get a taste of how to start-up a science/research based company. Workshops, including presentation and scientific writing skills and research ethics, were very beneficial to prepare students for their career at the next level. The research projects represented novel and critical research areas and the knowledge gained had improved the fundamental understanding and accelerated the development of these fields.

Broader Impacts: This project uniquely addressed the needs of the underserved Northeast Texas region and the border areas with a focus on the community college students which consist of a large fraction of minority, first generation college students, and veterans. The REU site at TAMU-Commerce has successfully served and will continue to serve as a model for addressing undergraduate research issues among community college students, an important population in the higher education ?pipeline? for STEM enrollments nationwide.
